universum.studios.android.fragment

Class BaseFragment

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.app.Fragment
      • universum.studios.android.fragment.BaseFragment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ComponentCallbacks, ComponentCallbacks2, View.OnCreateContextMenuListener, BackPressWatcher, ViewClickWatcher
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ActionBarFragment

    public abstract class BaseFragment
extends Fragment
implements BackPressWatcher, ViewClickWatcher
    A Fragment implementation designed to provide extended API and logic that is useful almost every time you need to implement your desired fragment.

    BaseFragment class provides lifecycle state check methods that may be used to check whether a particular instance of fragment is in a specific lifecycle state. All provided methods are listed below:

    • isAttached()
    • isCreated()
    • isStarted()
    • isPaused()
    • isStopped()
    • isDestroyed()
    as addition to the Android framework's lifecycle methods:
    • Fragment.isResumed()
    • Fragment.isDetached()

    You can also easily dispatch view click events to your specific implementation of BaseFragment via dispatchViewClick(View) or back press events via dispatchBackPress() from activity's context in which such fragment presented.

    Accepted annotations

    • @ContentView [class - inherited]

      If this annotation is presented, the layout resource specified via this annotation will be used to inflate root view for an instance of annotated BaseFragment sub-class when onCreateView(LayoutInflater, ViewGroup, Bundle) is called.

    Author:
    Martin Albedinsky

      • onAttach

        public void onAttach(Activity activity)
        Overrides:
        onAttach in class Fragment

      • isAttached

        public final boolean isAttached()
        Checks whether this fragment is attached to its parent context. This is true for duration of Fragment.onAttach(Context) and onDetach().

        When this method returns true the opposite lifecycle state method Fragment.isDetached() returns false and vise versa.

        Returns:
        True if fragment is attached, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        Fragment.isDetached()

      • getContextTheme

        @NonNull
protected Resources.Theme getContextTheme()
        Returns the theme of the context to which is this fragment attached.
        Returns:
        Parent context's theme.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If this fragment is not attached to any context.

      • dispatchViewClick

        public boolean dispatchViewClick(@NonNull
                                 View view)
        Dispatches to onViewClick(View).

        By default returns false for all passed views.

        Specified by:
        dispatchViewClick in interface ViewClickWatcher
        Parameters:
        view - The clicked view.
        Returns:
        True if this watcher processed the click event for the specified view, false otherwise.

      • onViewClick

        protected void onViewClick(@NonNull
                           View view)
        Invoked immediately after dispatchViewClick(View) was called to process click event on the given view.
        Parameters:
        view - The clicked view dispatched to this fragment.

      • startLoader

        @Nullable
public <D> Loader<D> startLoader(int id,
                                            @Nullable
                                            Bundle params,
                                            @NonNull
                                            LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks<D> callbacks)
        Starts a loader with the specified id. If there was already started loader with the same id before, such a loader will be re-started, otherwise new loader will be initialized.
        Parameters:
        id - Id of the desired loader to start.
        params - Params for loader.
        callbacks - Callbacks for loader.
        Returns:
        Initialized or re-started loader instance or null if the specified callbacks do not create loader for the specified id.
        See Also:
        initLoader(int, Bundle, LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks), restartLoader(int, Bundle, LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks), destroyLoader(int)

      • initLoader

public <D> Loader<D> initLoader(int id,

                                           Bundle params,
                                           @NonNull
                                           LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks<D> callbacks)
        Initializes a loader with the specified id for the given callbacks.
        Parameters:
        id - Id of the desired loader to init.
        params - Params for loader.
        callbacks - Callbacks for loader.
        Returns:
        Initialized loader instance or null if the specified callbacks do not create loader for the specified id.
        See Also:
        startLoader(int, Bundle, LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks), restartLoader(int, Bundle, LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks), destroyLoader(int), LoaderManager.initLoader(int, Bundle, LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks)

public <D> Loader<D> restartLoader(int id,

                                              Bundle params,

                                              LoaderManager.LoaderCallbacks<D> callbacks)

        id - Id of the desired loader to re-start.
        params - Params for loader.
        callbacks - Callbacks for loader.
        Returns:

        See Also:

        public void onPause()
        Overrides:
        onPause in class Fragment

      • isPaused

        public final boolean isPaused()
        Checks whether this fragment is in the paused lifecycle state. This is true for duration of onPause() until onResume() is called again.

        When this method returns true the opposite lifecycle state method Fragment.isResumed() returns false and vise versa.

        Returns:
        True if fragment has been paused, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        Fragment.isResumed()

      • onStop

        public void onStop()
        Overrides:
        onStop in class Fragment

      • isStopped

        public final boolean isStopped()
        Checks whether this fragment is in the stopped lifecycle state. This is true for duration of onStop() until onStart() is called again.

        When this method returns true the opposite lifecycle state method isStarted() returns false and vise versa.

        Returns:
        True if fragment has been stopped, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        isStarted()

        Description copied from interface: BackPressWatcher

        Specified by:

        Returns:
        True if this watcher processed the back press event, false otherwise.

      • onBackPress

        protected boolean onBackPress()
        Invoked immediately after dispatchBackPress() was called to process back press event.
        Returns:
        True if this instance of fragment has processed the back press event, false otherwise.

        Overrides:
        onDestroy in class Fragment

      • isDestroyed

        public final boolean isDestroyed()
        Checks whether this fragment is destroyed. This is true whenever onDestroy() has been called.

        When this method returns true the opposite lifecycle state method isCreated() returns false and vise versa.

        Returns:
        True if fragment is destroyed, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        isCreated()
